Award.AwardTitle: Merging Computer Science and Digital Arts: An Interdisciplinary Gaming and Simulation Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary project is designed to increase the number of students pursuing information technology careers by developing a new degree. Faculty members within Lehigh Carbon Community College's Computer Science and Digital Media departments are developing a two-track associate degree in Computer Game and Simulation Development. The curriculum is expected to prepare students for immediate employment as technicians as well as for transfer to four-year institutions. Strategies include learning communities, mentoring by professionals and internships with employers.

Outreach activities with high schools including summer camps for students and professional development for teachers enable a 2+2+2 career pathway. The partnership with employers, secondary schools and four-year institutions will have an impact on regional labor market needs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project created four programs of study in Computer Game and Simulation Development across two tracks: two focused on digital art and two on programming. There are career (A.A.S.) as well as transfer (A.A. and A.S.) programs available in both tracks. Industry representatives, through advisory board involvement, guided the direction of the curricula to ensure that the skills the students were developing would be aligned to industry standards and transferrable across many related career paths. A collaborative approach was used to design the six core game development courses that featured learning communities. In the early courses, students develop both art and programming skills through real-world assignments and then specialize when working on team projects in later courses.

 

These degree programs have enrolled 197 students over four years. In a survey of majors in all four programs, 55% indicated that they would not have attended Lehigh Carbon Community College if these degrees had not been offered.  All of the efforts to attract and retain students yielded a 69% retention rate over the course of any three consecutive fall/spring semesters, as per the data reported from the Spring 2015 semester. Of those students not retained in the degrees, 62% moved to related majors in computer science and the arts. While only 8% of students enrolled in the programming degree were female, 17% of students enrolled in the art degree were women. By linking the degrees so that they both include courses in computer science and art, all female students in the programs were exposed to programming and other computer science topics.

 

In addition to developing curricula, the PIs also created workshops to promote game development and STEM education to the larger community. Summer camps exposed 36 middle school students to game design and development, robotic programming, computational thinking, and STEM career choices. Through week-long workshops, teachers were instructed on the principles of effective educational game design. As a result, 60 teachers learned new techniques for engaging students via in-depth exploration and practice of subject matter through games. To facilitate this, an Edugaming Framework was developed by the PIs to guide the creation of effective educational games that do not rely on quizzing, leading to more engaging gameplay and more thorough reinforcement of content. All teachers were encouraged to involve their students in the polishing of their game designs thus exposing the students to the work that game designers do on a daily basis as a part of their careers. Anecdotally, workshop teachers have shared the positive results the games have had on student learning. Longer term data collection is planned as the games are tested with a larger number of classes of students.

 

The curricula, Edugaming Framework and results of the workshops have been widely disseminated at NSF ATE, League for Innovation, and Higher Education conferences thus exposing faculty from schools throughout the nation to the project activities, approach to the area of study, and implemented curricula.
